Examination of the medieval connotations of the term “ West” is complicated because it was understood and used in various ways prior to the thirteenth century, which is the focal point of the present study. To avoid as much ambiguity as possible, the term is used to designate the territories which generally acknowledged allegiance to the Roman Church. Thus, it will include Poland, Hungary, Bohemia, Moravia, Silesia, and the German states of eastern Europe, as well as England, France, and the Italian states which are regarded today as Western.
